Credit: Kevin Scott   Belfast Ralph HewittTwitterEmailFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailHolyland residents have instructed a Belfast law firm to consider taking immediate legal action against the PSNI, the Department for Justice and the city council in an effort to stop anti-social behaviour in the area.Phoenix Law’s Darragh Mackin confirmed a number of residents in the south Belfast area are looking to “challenge the current regime in place”.The Holyland area has been plagued for years by anti-social behaviour from both young people and a minority of university students moving into the area.Almost  young people gathered for a street party during Freshers’ Week in September, resulting in three arrests and more than , bottles of alcohol being confiscated by police.The PSNI increased patrols in the Holyland during Freshers’ Week and St Patrick’s Day, handing out a number of Covid notices. But the problems continued to persist.Police were also investigating an incident in October where footage on social media appeared to show a group of iniduals throwing a plant pot at a resident’s car.Phoenix Law partner Mr Mackin stressed the potential legal action is aimed at protecting permanent residents in the area by ensuring safeguards are in place.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “This is not a situation whereby it is residents against students as often inferred,” he told the Belfast . “In fact, it is the very opposite. The reality is the residents have been, and continue to be, let down by the ineffective practices and procedures in place to protect those iniduals who live in the area.“It is the worst kept secret that there continues to be illegal occupation of multiple person properties with little or no review or investigation.“Further, the area continues to produce high levels of anti-social behaviour with limited and intermittent policing response.”Mr Mackin added that residents have been left to fend for themselves “for too long”. “We are now instructed to consider immediate legal action against both the council, the department and the PSNI for failing to ensure the necessary protections and safeguards are in place for those residents who we represent,” he stated.Long-time residents’ campaigner Brid Ruddy, who is one of the Holyland residents involved in the case, welcomed the expected legal action. She agreed with Mr Mackin that the issues in the area are not “a tussle” between dfering lestyles of residents and students, but a failure by relevant agencies to put an end to noise complaints, fly-tipping, anti-social behaviour and houses of multiple occupancy .“Yes, a lot of the anti-social behaviour comes from a minority of students who are a disgrace to the student body, because not all students are like that, but the cause of it is the total failure by the agencies to really look after this area,” stated Ms Ruddy.“It has been left to degenerate into an HMO slum.”Reflecting on the trouble within the Holyland over the past year, Ms Ruddy said it never gets any better and now occurs seven days a week. She added that people go to the area to party because “they know there will be no repercussions” and said the “absurdity of it all” was highlighted when a communal Christmas tree installed by residents was stolen in early December.“The police and council just keep saying they’re working in partnership models with others,” said Ms Ruddy. “The partnership model doesn’t work. We can’t keep on doing the same thing and expecting a dferent result.”The PSNI, Belfast City Council and the Department for Justice all said they have not received any correspondence relating to legal Credit: Bernie BrownClaire McNeillyTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailOnly a few miles separate Tigers Bay and Clonard Monastery.In Northern Ireland historical terms, however, the two Belfast venues could hardly be further apart.One is a bastion of Ulster Protestantism, the other a citadel of northern Catholicism.But things are changing, and it was hard to escape the importance of the symbolism when Tigers Bay native Carl Frampton spoke at the west Belfast venue.The world champion boxer, emblematic of a more optimistic, post-conflict Northern Ireland, was a key speaker at the  Corners cross-community festival, the aim of which is to bring people together to focus on similarities rather than dferences.Others last week included the Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby and Pope Francis — albeit via a video message — but Carl was more than happy to be there personally to address a large, wide audience and help the festival celebrate its th anniversary.It included former DUP MP Emma Little Pengelly and Belfast-born Northern Ireland Office minister Conor Burns — who heard Carl say he would be “too honest” to ever get involved in politics.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “The  Corners was something I wanted to be involved in,” the two-weight title winner told the Belfast .“It’s good to do these sorts of things.“I feel like when you’ve been given a , you should try to use it to have a positive effect and that’s what I always try to do.”The -year-old, who describes himself as “more spiritual than religious”, added: “There was a large group of kids from east Belfast and where there a wide-ranging crowd, and something you might not have seen in a Catholic church too often in the past.“I’ve never done one in a Catholic church before, so it’s a new string to my bow.“It was a beautul setting as well.”Conservative MP Mr Burns —whose remark about Prime Minister Boris Johnson being “hijacked by a cake” became a global news story recently — was one of those who participated in the ‘Carl at Clonard’ question and answer session, hosted by broadcast journalist Mark Sidebottom.Mr Burns asked him what politicians can learn from sport, to which Carl replied: “I likened it to boxing. “I told him that what we see in politics at the minute is a lot of aggression.“There’s also a lot of anger between communities in Northern Ireland at the minute, and I don’t think politicians help that. I’ve seen it behind the scenes.The aggression that they’re showing is what people soak up, but behind the scenes it’s not like that.“They’re shaking hands and smiling at each other... behind the scenes, when the doors are closed, it’s not as aggressive as it comes across on the TV or in the newspapers when journalists are interviewing them.“In boxing, you can fight hard with someone for  rounds, blood, sweat and tears, but there’s an embrace at the end and respect shown and there doesn’t seem to be that respect in politicians at the minute.”He added: “Another thing I said, when I was askedI would ever go into politics — was that the answer is always no.“One of the reasons for that answer — and I’m not having a dig here — is that I feel like I’m too honest to be a politician.“I don’t feel clever enough to give a politician’s answer to questions — you see them being asked something and they just waffle on without actually answering it and they get away with it all the time.“I don’t think I would have the brain power to do that.”Carl said the Clonard session was emotional for him in parts.“At one point I was askedI ever cried outside of boxing and I said I cry a lot,” he added.“I actually cried that day because my we Christine’s cousin, who was younger than her, passed away.“I’d just had a video sent through that morning and it was hard to watch because it was upsetting.“There were pictures of her and her kids. It was heartbreaking to see a young girl lose her le, leaving two kids behind.“And I almost cried talking about it — I kind of held the tears back — but I got emotional, and I wasn’t expecting that.”Did the audience seem surprised to see a tough boxer cry “I think so, probably, but anybody close to me wouldn’t be surprised by me shedding a few tears, to be honest.”The  CornersFestival takes place annually around this time of year and comprises a range of events featuring discussion, music, prayer, drama, poetry and storytelling in venues across the city.A registered charity, it was set up a decade ago by Presbyterian minister Rev Steve Stockman and Catholic priest Fr Martin Magill.Related topicsCarl Frampton MBEBoris JohnsonMore On Carl Frampton MBE PremiumCarl FramptonOpinionI FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueStormont.Garrett HarganTwitterEmailFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailMLAs will meet at Stormont for the first time since Paul Givan announced his resignation as First Minister.Local representatives will meet the Speaker Alex Maskey on Monday morning to discuss how legislation can be progressed.In a letter to MLAs following the First Minister’s resignation, Mr Maskey said: “The Assembly will continue to carry out business until dissolution takes place.Read MoreGive NI crisis the attention it deserves, DUP chief tells BorisAllison Morris:OpinionDUP’s Donaldson is gambling with his future and the Union“The Business Committee will schedule sittings of the Assembly as normal and the scrutiny of Executive legislation and Private Members’ Bills going through the Assembly can continue.“While the wider political environment may not make things easier, I will remain focused on working with parties to deal with as much legislation as possible in the time available.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The dissolution of the Assembly is expected to occur at midnight on March , .At Westminster a law is due to be passed on Monday that would protect the NI Assembly from collapse.It would remove the need for the NI secretary to set a date for an electionthe positions of First and Deputy First Minister are not filled by the end of the week.The NI Ministers, Elections and Petitions of Concern Bill would allow the NI Assembly to continue without a ing Executive for at least six months.During that time ministers would be able to run their departments.The legislation could also take effect after the assembly election in May  parties fail to fill the positions of First and Deputy First Minister.A House of Lords amendment to the bill would allow the legislation to be applied retrospectively.The next step for the legislation, which was agreed under the New Decade, New Approach deal to restore power-sharing in , will then be sent for royal assent.Paul Givan resigned as First Minister on February . Credit: Kelvin Boyes   Press Eye FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe £ Spend Local cardAmy CochraneTwitterEmailFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailIt has been revealed that , emails sent by the Department of the Economy to high street voucher cardholders in Northern Ireland in December included the wrong telephone number.They were followed by a further , emails including the correct number the following day, according to Economy Minister Gordon Lyons.The Spend Local scheme was launched by the minister in October .All householders across Northern Ireland were eligible for a pre-paid card to spend in local shops under one of Stormont’s flagship post-Covid economic stimulus policies.By the time applications closed, nearly .m cards had been circulated.Read MoreHigh Street scheme payments to , accounts ‘won’t have to be spent local’The scheme, however, was not without its problems.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Despite the deadline to use the cards being extended a number of times late last year, some people were not been able to spend the money, because of issues including postage delivery failures, technical problems in activating the cards or administrative mistakes by the Economy Department.A few days before the deadline of December , , the department had sent emails to cardholders asking them to spend the remaining balance on their cards.But the inclusion of the incorrect phone number led to Bangor businesswoman, Helen McMahon, who owns a first aid training company, receiving over , phone calls from members of the public querying issues with their cards.Ulster Unionist MLA Alan Chambers posed a question to the Economy Minister asking whether the owner of the phone number had been in touch with the department and whether any arrangements have been put in place to mitigate the number of calls the owner may receive.Mt Lyons replied to both questions simply ‘yes’.North Down MLA Mr Chambers then followed up with the question asking how many people were sent the email, to which the minister confirmed there were , people who received the email who had above £ in their card balance.Mr Lyons claried in his reply that the last digit of the phone number was incorrect.Mr Chambers said: “It is human error, but you would expect a government department to proof check any information they send out, and in particular a phone number.“My office dealt with a huge number of applicants who missed out on the scheme through no fault of their own.“We have continued to fight their cause and the minister has now introduced a scheme to place £ directly into the bank account of those who lost out.“Hopefully this damage limitation exercise will proceed in a more efficient manner than some other elements of the scheme have been conducted.”It is predicted that around , people will receive £ into their bank accounts who had not received a card.Unlike those who did receive a card, it is understood that there will be no restrictions on where you can spend it.At the end of last month, Mr Lyons announced that his department would spend up to £.m on making the payments to people who didn’t get their cards, or weren’t able to use them properly, through the BACS system of money transfer.The department, which is administering the £m scheme, did not respond when askedthe use of the cash would be limited to spending in bricks and mortar shops. It did not comment when asked about how much of the £.m was intended for bank charges.Mr Lyons said the scheme had been a huge success, with .m cards dispatched, and spending using the cards had boosted the economy by £.m.Related topicsGordon LyonsDepartment for the EconomyUlster Unionist PartyAlan ChambersMore On Gordon Lyons PremiumViewpointOpinionWorking at home now a viable option title: watch surging waves engulf cars at benone strand
story: These were the dramatic scenes after a high tide sent waves surging up to a car parking site on Benone Strand.Local woman Anna Isaksson captured the footage yesterday showing the aftermath as the water rushed towards the crowds gathered on the beach near Limavady.Soon afterwards, cars could be seen surrounded by water, while empty pet baskets were also swept away – fortunately, no animals were harmed.Anna explained how the incident quickly unfolded.She said at one stage the vehicles were “completely swamped”.“We were there possibly just before am. A lot of people drive down and park on the beach. It was meant to be after high tide,” she said.“We have enough experience on that beach – you think we’d know better, but we walked up to go and get a coffee and the waves were coming right in, past the coffee area right at the top there.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “All the cars were getting completely swamped, there were a few animal baskets getting dragged away, luckily there were no animals in there, all animals were safe.“It was just crazy.“There were a group of ladies going in for a swim and a few of us were a bit concerned. We were saying ‘Be careful, maybe don’t go in or,you are, maybe don’t go too deep’. Then that surge came in, just before they went into the water, thank goodness, it would have been enough to take them off their feetthey had been in.”Anna said people need to be wary of strong currents.“The pull is so strong back out again,” she added.“That is why we have been putting up messages on social media for people to stay out of the water oryou are going into the water make sure you do an appropriate risk assessment and don’t go in far. I would just say don’t go in, to be honest.“When you first drive down you don’t think it is so bad but the waves out far are really big and they are breaking really big.“We drove round to Portstewart as well and because the waves are breaking so close to shore you can see the size of them.“I know the reports are that it is going to be building all day. Hopefully the surges won’t be coming up quite as far with the tide going out.”Locals said the surging waves can happen frequently.A spokesperson for Maritime and Coast Guard Control based in Bangor said further wave surges were expected into the afternoon yesterday, but the worst had passed.They encouraged the public not to put themselves into danger attempting to capture any photographs, never to turn their back on waves and to “stay high and stay dry”, by keeping away from dangerous and rough sea conditions.Most ReadWatch: Surging waves engulf cars at Benone StrandDonna Traynor
